natural solution: \end{align}Applying the product-to-sum formula again, we get \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left( -\frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ + \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ \right) &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left( -\frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ + \frac{\cos 30^\circ + \cos 10^\circ}{2} \right) \\

 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \cos 10^\circ (\cos 120^\circ + \cos 20^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (\cos 10^\circ \cos 120^\circ + \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left( -\frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ + \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ \right).

The final answer is 3/16."

theorem
fixes cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {10, 30, 50, 70} \<longrightarrow> cos x \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "cos 10 * cos 30 * cos 50 * cos 70 = r"
shows  "r = 3/16"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify $\cos 10^\circ \cos 30^\circ \cos 50^\circ \cos 70^\circ.$ The final Answer is \frac{3}{16}
 ### Proof

 \end{align}Applying the product-to-sum formula again, we get \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left( -\frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ + \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ \right) &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left( -\frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ + \frac{\cos 30^\circ + \cos 10^\circ}{2} \right) \\
 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8} \cos 30^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\frac{3}{16}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {10, 30, 50, 70} \<longrightarrow> cos x \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "cos 10 * cos 30 * cos 50 * cos 70 = r"
shows  "r = 3/16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
